case_name: M/s. Chugamal Rajpal v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1311 of 1967 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1311 of 1967. Appeal by special le

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 17, 1967 of the Patna High Court in C.W.J.C. No. 952 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 17, 1967 of the Patna High Court in C.W.J.C. No. 952 of 1966. C. Chagla, N. D. Karkhanis, S. P. Chowdhury, Bhuvanesh Kumari, for the appellant.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed the writ petition under Articles 226 and 227 in limine.

anchor.surface_text: This is an assessees, appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Patna dismissing in limini its writ petition under Arts 226 and 227 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: The assessee is a partnership firm having construction contracts under the Railways as well as the Government.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is having companystruction companytracts under the Railways as well as the Government. It is a partnership firm.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1960-61, relevant to the accounting year 1959-60, the assessee submitted its income-tax return.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1960-61, relevant to the accounting year 1959-60, after the assessee submitted its income-tax return, it was asked by the Income-tax Officer during the income-tax assessment proceedings to produce before him its books of account and the other relevant papers.

facts.text: The assessee produced books of account and statement showing various creditors from whom it had borrowed on Hundis during 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: it was asked by the Income-tax Officer during the income-tax assessment proceedings to produce before him its books of account and the other relevant papers. The assessee also produced before him a statement showing various creditors from whom it had borrowed on Hundis during the accounting year in question.

facts.text: After enquiry, the assessee's total income was assessed at Rs. 69,886/- for AY 1960-61.

anchor.surface_text: In that statement it gave the lull names and address of the alleged creditors. After enquiry, the assessees total income was assessed at Rs. 69,886/-.

facts.text: On June 3, 1966, the Income-tax Officer Ward A, Muzaffarpur issued notice under s. 148 to the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: On June 3, 1966, the 1st respondent  Income-tax Officer Ward A,, Muzaffarpur  issued to the assessee a numberice under s. 148 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1961.

facts.text: The notice under s.148 was for AY 1960-61 claiming income escaped assessment under s.147.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas  1  have reason to believe that your income chargeable the income of 1960-1961 in respect of which you are assessable to tax for the assessment year 19 19 has escaped assessment within the meaning of section 147 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.

facts.text: The notice was issued after obtaining satisfaction of the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice is being issued after obtaining the necessary satisfaction of the Commissioner of IncomeTax, Bihar and Orissa, Patna.

facts.text: The assessee challenged the validity of the notice and proceedings taken on its strength.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee challenged the validity of that numberice as well as proceedings taken on the strength of that numberice on various grounds.

facts.text: The notice was issued after four years but before eight years of the original assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the numberice was issued after four years but before eight years of the date of the original assessment.

facts.text: On previous hearing, the Court directed production of records to show compliance with s.148 and s.151(2).

anchor.surface_text: When this appeal came up for hearing on the last occasion, as we found the affidavit filed by the Income-tax Officer to be vague and indefinite, we directed the learned Counsel for the Department to produce before us the records of the Incometax Officer to show that the, Income-tax Officer had companyplied with the requirements of s. 148 and s. 151 2  of the Act.

facts.text: On 18th January 1971, only the ITO's report to CIT and CIT's order were produced, no order sheet for s.148(2) reasons.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was taken up for hearing on the 18th January 1971, only the report submitted by the Income- tax Officer to the Commissioner and the order of the Commissioner was produced. The order sheet recording the reasons of the Income-tax Officer as required by s. 148 2  was number produced.

facts.text: ITO's report dated 30-4-1966 proposed notice u/s 148 for AY 1960-61.

facts.text: CIT satisfied on 13-5-1966 that it is fit case for notice u/s 148.

facts.text: Assessee showed loans from various Calcutta parties on Hundis during the year.

anchor.surface_text: During the year the assessee hasshown to have taken loans from various parties of Calcutta.

facts.text: Information from D.I.'s Inv. No. AP/Misc. 5 D.I./63-64/5623 dated 13-8-65 indicated name lenders and bogus transactions.

anchor.surface_text: From D.I.s Inv. No. A P/ Misc.  5 D.I./63-64/5623 dated 13-8-65, forwarded to this office under C.I.T. Bihar and Orissa, Patnas letter No. Inv.  Inv.  15/ 65-66/1953-2017 dated Patna 24-9-65, it appears that these persons are name lenders and the transactions are bogus.

facts.text: Names of some alleged Hundi lenders: Seth Bhagwan Singh Sricharan, Lakha Singh Lal Singh, Radhakissen Shyam Sunder.

anchor.surface_text: The name of some of the persons from whom money is alleged to have taken on loan on Hundis are Seth Bhagwan Singh Sricharan. Lakha Singh Lal Singh. Radhakissen Shyam Sunder.

facts.text: Amount of escapement involved Rs. 100,000/- as per ITO report.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of escapement involved amounts to Rs. 100,000/-.

facts.text: Originally assessed income Rs. 73,604/- as per ITO report.

anchor.surface_text: the income  or loss or depreciation allowance  originally assessed determined. Rs. 73,604/-

facts.text: Supreme Court held the notice invalid for non-compliance with s.151(2).

anchor.surface_text: As we are accepting the companytention of the assessee that the impugned numberice is invalid inasmuch as it did number companyply with the requirements of s. 151 2  of the Act

facts.text: ITO's report did not set out reasons for believing it fit case under s.148.

anchor.surface_text: In his report the Income-tax Officer does number set out any reason for companying to the companyclusion that this is a fit case to issue numberice under s. 148.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, quashed the notice.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed, the order of the High Court is set aside and the impugned numberice quashed.

issues.text: Whether the impugned notice under s.148 is invalid for non-compliance with the requirements of s.151(2)?

anchor.surface_text: The assessee challenged the validity of that notice as well as proceedings taken on the strength of that notice on various grounds. As we are accepting the contention of the assessee that the impugned notice is invalid inasmuch as it did not comply with the requirements of s. 151 2  of the Act, we have not thought it necessary to examine the other contentions advanced on behalf of the assessee.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer recorded reasons for issuing the notice under s.148(2)?

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was taken up for hearing on the 18th January 1971, only the report submitted by the Income- tax Officer to the Commissioner and the order of the Commissioner was produced. The order sheet recording the reasons of the Income-tax Officer as required by s. 148 2  was not produced.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer's report provided sufficient reasons recorded for the Commissioner to be satisfied under s.151(2) that it is a fit case for issuing notice under s.148?

anchor.surface_text: In his report the Income-tax Officer does not set out any reason for coming to the conclusion that this is a fit case to issue notice under s. 148. The material that he had before him for issuing notice under s. 148 is not mentioned in the report. In his report he vaguely refers to certain communications received by him from the C.I.T., Bihar and Orissa.

issues.text: Whether the Commissioner properly recorded satisfaction under s.151(2) on the ITO's reasons for issuing the notice?

anchor.surface_text: Further the report submitted by him under s. 151 2  does not mention any reason for coming to the conclusion that it is a fit case for the issue of a notice under s. 148. We are also of the opinion that the Commissioner has mechanically accorded permission. He did not himself record that he was satisfied that this was a fit case for the issue of a notice under s. 148.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had reasons to believe that income chargeable to tax had escaped assessment within the meaning of s.147(a) or (b)?

anchor.surface_text: Before issuing a notice under s. 148, the Income-tax Officer must have either reasons to believe that by reason of the omission or failure on the part of the assessee to make a return under s. 139 for any assessment year to the Income-tax Officer or to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for that year, income chargeable to tax has escaped assessment for that year or alternatively notwithstanding that there has been no omission or failure as mentioned above on the part of the assessee, the Income-tax Officer has in consequence of information in his possession reason to believe that income chargeable to tax has escaped assessment for any assessment year.

arguments.claim: Notice issued after four years requires compliance with s.151(2): Commissioner satisfied on reasons recorded by ITO

anchor.surface_text: In this case the notice was issued after four years but before eight years of the date of the original assessment. Section 151 (2) of the Act reads No notice shall be issued under Section 148 after the expiry of four years from the end of the relevant assessment year, unless the Commissioner is satisfied on the reasons recorded by the Income-tax Officer that it is a fit case for the issue of such notice.

arguments.claim: s.148 requires ITO to record reasons before issuing notice

anchor.surface_text: Section 148 prescribes Before making the assessment, re-assessment or recomputation under Section 147, the Income-tax Officer shall serve on the assessee a notice containing all or any of the requirements which may be included in a notice under sub- section  2  of Section 139 and the provisions of this Act shall, so far as may be, apply accordingly as if the notice were a notice issued under that sub-section.

arguments.claim: Order sheet recording reasons under s.148(2) was not produced indicating non-compliance

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was taken up for hearing on the 18th January 1971, only the report submitted by the Income- tax Officer to the Commissioner and the order of the Commissioner was produced. The order sheet recording the reasons of the Income-tax Officer as required by s. 148 2  was not produced.

arguments.claim: ITO report does not set out any reason for concluding fit case under s.148; material not mentioned; vague

anchor.surface_text: In his report the Income-tax Officer does not set out any reason for coming to the conclusion that this is a fit case to issue notice under s. 148. The material that he had before him for issuing notice under s. 148 is not mentioned in the report. In his report he vaguely refers to certain communications received by him from the C.I.T., Bihar and Orissa.

arguments.claim: No prima facie conclusion by ITO that transactions not genuine; only vague feeling

anchor.surface_text: He does not mention the facts contained in those communications. All that he says is that from those communications it appears that these persons  alleged creditors  are name lenders and the transactions are bogus. He has not even come to a prima facie conclusion that the transactions to which he referred are not genuine transactions.

arguments.claim: Such conclusion does not fulfil requirements of s.151(2); must give reasons/prima facie grounds

anchor.surface_text: Such a conclusion does not fulfil the requirements of s. 151 2 . What that provision requires is that he must give reasons for issuing a notice under s. 148. In other words he must have some prima facie grounds before him for taking action under s.

arguments.claim: 'Proper investigation necessary' not equivalent to reasons to issue notice under s.148

anchor.surface_text: Further his report mentions Hence proper investigation regarding these loans is necessary In other words his conclusion is that there is a case for investigating as to the truth of the alleged transactions. That is not the same thing as saying that there are reasons to issue, notice under s. 148.

arguments.claim: To issue notice u/s148, ITO must have reasons to believe escaped assessment under s.147(a) or (b)

anchor.surface_text: Before issuing a notice under s. 148, the Income-tax Officer must have either reasons to believe that by reason of the omission or failure on the part of the assessee to make a return under s. 139 for any assessment year to the Income-tax Officer or to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for that year,

arguments.claim: No material satisfying s.147(a) or (b); no jurisdiction to issue notice

anchor.surface_text: Unless the requirements of clause (a) or (b) of s. 147 are satisfied, the Income-tax Officer has no jurisdiction to issue a notice under s. 148.

arguments.claim: From ITO report, no reasons to believe under s.147(a) or (b)

anchor.surface_text: From the report submitted by the Income-tax Officer to the Commissioner, it is clear that he could not have had reasons to believe that by reason of the assessees omission to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for the accounting year in question, income chargeable to tax has escaped assessment for that year nor could it be said that he as a consequence of information in his possession,

arguments.claim: CIT mechanically accorded permission; did not record satisfaction that fit case
arguments.qualifiers: We are also of the opinion

arguments.claim: Important safeguards in ss.147 and 151 lightly treated by ITO and CIT; form over substance

anchor.surface_text: The important safeguards provided in sections 147 and 151 were lightly treated by the Income-tax Officer as well as by the Commissioner Both of them, appear to have taken the duty imposed on them under those provisions as of little importance. They have substituted the form for the substance.

anchor.surface_text: the impugned notice is invalid inasmuch as it did not comply with the requirements of s. 151 2  of the Act, we have not thought it necessary to examine the other contentions advanced on behalf of the assessee.
